page.title: 11 - ECOLOGY AND LANDSCAPE
page.content:
The area is still very rural and there is a wide variation in flora and fauna.
The three ponds, Chingford, Burton, and Black, all have resident and visiting birdlife including swans, geese and ducks, and dragon flies are also a frequent occurence.
Alders are the most common tree in the wetter areas, whereas to the south the heathland has many silver birches and a lot of bracken. Burton Park contains many fine trees including sweet chestnuts now past their prime, planted by former owners.
There are two small nature reserves in the area, and it is home for a large rabbit population. Deer are frequently seen as well.
